title: Your Terminal as Creative Space
description: Why terminal-first development creates conditions for focused creation.

sections.text: What if your tools could disappear?
sections.subtitle: Not gone. Just invisible. So focused on the work that you forget the tool exists.

sections.explanation: When a tool works, you don't see it. You see what you're making. Heidegger called this 'Zuhandenheit'—the tool recedes into transparent use. Your terminal can become this.

sections.caption: Watch the focus shift from tool to work. The hammer fades. Only the nail remains.

sections.explanation: Panels, buttons, notifications—they're 'present-at-hand.' You notice the tool instead of your work. Terminal-first development inverts this.

sections.caption: From chrome to canvas. Watch the interface dissolve until only your work remains.

messages: The terminal is a blank canvas.
It shows exactly what you need.
With practice, it becomes an extension of thought.

steps.command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install wezterm
steps.note: See docs for GPG key setup

sections.title: Canon Configuration
sections.code:
local wezterm = require 'wezterm'
local config = wezterm.config_builder()

-- Canon colors: pure black, white foreground
config.colors = {
  background = '#000000',
  foreground = '#ffffff',
  cursor_bg = '#ffffff',
  cursor_fg = '#000000',
}

-- Minimal chrome
config.enable_tab_bar = false
config.window_decorations = 'RESIZE'
config.window_padding = {
  left = 12, right = 12,
  top = 12, bottom = 12,
}

-- Font
config.font = wezterm.font('JetBrains Mono')
config.font_size = 14.0

return config

messages: Every pixel of chrome is a pixel of distraction.
The blank canvas creates space for thought.

sections.prompt: Look at your new terminal. What's missing?
sections.answer: Nothing is missing. The absence is the design.

sections.prompt: How does this feel compared to your previous environment?
sections.answer: Quieter. More focused. The tool has receded.

sections.explanation: This is Dieter Rams' principle. Every element must earn its place. Your terminal has nothing to prove—it simply serves your work.
